I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In December 2003, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in consultation with the Ministry 
of Agriculture, Water Resources and Processing Industry (MAWRPI) initiated a concept paper to 
undertake  a  study  of  the  impact  of  land  reform  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  paper  was 
subsequently supported for funding by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund. A Fact-Finding 
Mission that visited the Kyrgyz Republic on 15 March–2 April 2004 to formulate the technical 
assistance (TA) reached an understanding with the Government on the goal, purpose, scope, 
implementation arrangements, cost estimates, financing arrangements, and terms of reference 
for the TA.1 The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The Kyrgyz Republic is a predominantly agricultural economy, with the agriculture sector 
contributing in 2002 more than a third of the country’s gross domestic product, 11% of the 
economy’s  export  earnings,  and  52%  of  total  employment.  About  66%  of  the  country’s 
population live in the rural areas and depend on agriculture for their livelihood. Since 1996, 
agriculture has contributed significantly to economic recovery, growing at an average annual 
rate of about 7.4% (1996–2002) compared with 4.7% for the economy as a whole.  
 
3.  Structural reforms in the sector have helped agriculture to recover. The land reform and 
farm restructuring reforms introduced in 1993 were some of the key measures that seem to 
have stimulated agricultural growth in the second half of the 1990s. In Central Asia, the Kyrgyz 
Republic  was  the  forerunner  in  land  reform  and  farm  restructuring  legislation  and 
implementation. The reform measures, implemented through several phases, comprised the 
privatization  of  state  and  collective  farms  into  privately  owned  farms,  establishment  of 
institutions  to  support  the  process,  and  introduction  of  a  market-oriented  land  market. 
Privatization of the former state and collective farms is almost complete. Of the country’s arable 
land, 75% has been reallocated. About 243,294 private peasant and individual farmers are using 
752,656 hectares (ha) (Agriculture Census, 2002). Land legislation and land-related institutions 
at  national  and  local  government  levels  are  undergoing  transformation  to  facilitate  the 
decentralization of land management at the oblast (region), raion (district), and aiyl okmotu 
(village) levels; facilitate land market development; and implement a land registration system. 
 
4.  According to the Agricultural Census (2002), of 1,038,997 farms with arable land of 
1,306,786 ha, 85.1% are less than 1 ha; 23% are peasant or individual farms holding 57.6% of 
arable land (average size 3.09 ha); and 76.4% are individual (household) plots holding 4.9% of 
arable land (average size 0.08 ha). These farms grow essentially subsistence crops as they 
have little scope for agriculture improvement. Aside from the large number of small farm plot 
owners, other production arrangements have emerged because of land reform. They vary in 
land size and farm management, and hence have different production needs for growth. 
 
5.  Implementation  of  the  land  reform  program  continues  and  considerable  challenges 
remain. A recent study2 identified five major areas of concern: (i) the allocation, use, and local 
public management of the Land Redistribution Fund (LRF);3 (ii) lack of a pastureland policy

the growing demand for pasturelands with the resurgence of the livestock sector; (iii) the need to 
assess the land market restrictions and property rights in terms of household land shares, family 
property, married women’s rights to land ownership, and regional variations in lease rental 
markets; (iv) the need to accelerate the registration of farms and clarify technical issues; and (v) 
the rise of land-related conflicts and how best to address these disputes. The land-related 
institutions  are  still  building  their  capacity  and  face  difficulties  in  meeting  the  demand  for 
services at the same time as policy and legislation undergo amendment and harmonization. For 
example,  having  previously  undertaken  the  registration  of  urban  properties,  GosRegister 
recently began the registration of rural properties. Land-related institutions at the oblast, raion, 
and  aiyl  okmotu  levels  are  technically  ill-equipped  to  implement  land  reform,  and  local 
governments have limited understanding of the various land laws and policies. 
 
6.  Poverty incidence in the Kyrgyz Republic in 2002 was exemplified by 44.4% of the 
population living in absolute poverty and 13.8% living in extreme poverty.4 Poverty incidence in 
rural areas declined over 1998–2001 largely due to the better performance of the agriculture 
sector. However, rural poverty continues to be significantly higher than urban poverty: About two 
thirds of the population living in rural areas comprise about three quarters of the poor people 
(2001).  There  are  significant  regional  differences  in  poverty:  Naryn  oblast  has  the  highest 
incidence of poverty, followed by Talas, the three southern oblasts of Jalal-Abad, Osh, and 
Batken,  and  the  northern  oblast  of  Issyk-Kul;  the  least  poor  area  is  Chui  oblast.  Another 
important feature of poverty is that the majority of the population live very close to the margin 
between poor and non-poor, thus creating a significant degree (about 39% in 2001) of transient 
poverty. 
 
7.  The aid community and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) have played a major role 
in  assisting  the  Government  in  formulating  and  modifying  policy  and  legislation  and  in 
implementing the land reform program. Key support has come from the World Bank through the 
Agriculture Support Services Project (ASSP) and the Real Estate and Registration Projects, and 
from  the  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)  through  the  Legal 
Infrastructure for a Market Economy,  Kyrgyz Land Reform, and Legal Assistance to Rural 
Citizens (with Helvetas) projects. Recent support from both international agencies and some 
NGOs has focused on legal advice to farmers in resolving their land disputes as well as public 
information campaigns to local governments and farmers. Systematic monitoring of land reform 
appears to be limited to ASSP, which has conducted farm surveys in 1999 and 2001, with the 
2003 survey currently under way. There have been other smaller and one-off surveys, often 
supporting the specific objectives and focus of respective projects. 
 
8.  Neither the land reform process nor the impact of land reform has been systematically 
monitored and assessed. Experience elsewhere indicates a strong causal relationship between 
landownership  (through  land  reform)  and  agriculture  growth,  primarily  through  increased 
productivity of smaller farms relative to large farms. Small farm owners who benefited from land 
reform often invest in land improvements and use quality inputs as well as increase labor 
intensity. Poverty incidence among land reform beneficiaries also tends to decline. Secure rights 
to land have likewise been linked to fostering environmental stewardship and use of sustainable

farm practices. However, other studies also showed that the positive impact of land reform on 
agriculture growth, poverty reduction, and environment may be short-lived unless these one-
time effects of land reform are accompanied with complementary institutional and additional 
legislative  reforms,  the  establishment  of  input  markets,  and  development  of  market-  and 
productivity-enhancing  infrastructure  facilities.  Similarly,  ad  hoc  studies  done  in  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic, which use cross-sectional data, reflect the same short-term beneficial effects of land 
reform. However, there is a dearth of comprehensive analysis that looks at the processes and 
their  implications  for  further  poverty  reduction,  increased  productivity,  and  sustainable 
environmental development.  
 
9.  A comprehensive study of the Kyrgyz Republic’s land reform program is considered 
timely. The study can review the process from its origin, particularly the evolution of the policy, 
legislation, and institutions; and assess their impact on agricultural growth, poverty, and the 
environment. Such a study will assist the Government in the next phase of the program, which 
will see a consolidation of policy, legislation, and institutions. This phase should ensure the 
positive contribution of the reformed lands to sustainable agriculture and rural development, 
reduction  in  poverty,  and  improved  environmental  practices.  The  study  will  provide 
recommendations on the Government's next agenda for action. At the same time, the study will 
be useful to other transition economies, especially the Central Asian countries, by identifying the 
major lessons learned and good practice in formulating and implementing an efficient and 
effective land reform program. The study will also provide a basis for ADB and other sources of 
aid  to  incorporate  relevant  recommendations in  future  technical  assistance  and investment 
projects. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  The goal of the TA is to implement a more efficient and effective land reform program in 
the Kyrgyz Republic and other transition economies. Its purpose is to assess the process and 
impact of land reform on agricultural growth, poverty reduction, and the environment. The final 
report including recommendations and lessons learned will be published. The outputs of the TA 
include (i) an assessment of the process of land reform; (ii) an assessment of the impact of land 
reform on agricultural growth, poverty reduction, and the environment; (iii) case studies in three 
oblasts to identify good practices in implementation, participatory methods, gender aspects, and 
understanding of farmers' rights; and (iv) local and national workshops. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA is principally an analytical study of both the process and the impact of land 
reform on agriculture, poverty reduction, and the environment, especially pastures. The study 
will employ a strong collaborative and participatory approach to ensure widespread involvement 
and agreement on the analysis and recommendations. This collaboration and participation will 
be pursued through the establishment of a multi-stakeholder study coordination group, extensive 
group interviews, comprehensive and in-depth survey, several workshops at local and national 
levels, and a final workshop involving international participants. 
 
12.  An  important  feature  of  the  study  will  be  the  emphasis  on  collaboration  between 
international and domestic consultants and resource personnel. This collaboration will be of 
mutual  benefit,  with  the  local  personnel  gaining  valuable  knowledge  and  experience  in  a 
rigorous and systematic study and the international consultants gaining understanding of the

4 
local social, cultural, and institutional contexts. The framework of analysis will be in the political 
economy and institutional economics context of the Kyrgyz Republic. 
 
13.  Essentially, the key activities will include 
 
(i)  reviews of key literature on land reform in relevant countries, the evolution of the 
process and key policy documents and legislation, the evolution of institutions in 
response to the changing policy and legislation environment and land reform 
implementation  requirements,  the  role  of  all  stakeholders  in  formulating  and 
implementing the land reform program, and available statistics and surveys; 
(ii)  a  systematic  assessment  of  impact  through  a  quantitative  and  qualitative 
analysis. Where feasible use will be made of panel data from Agriculture Census 
2002, surveys under ASSP, and household budget survey for 2000, 2001, and 
2002. Additional quantitative and qualitative surveys will be undertaken in the 
three  oblasts  of  Osh  representing  the  southern  area,  Chui  representing  the 
northern area, and Naryn representing the importance of pasturelands. All data 
and analysis will be disaggregated by gender, region, indigenous groups, where 
significant; and farm type (structure, ownership, and management); 
(iii)  preparation of case studies for each surveyed oblast of Chui, Naryn, and Osh to 
focus on the common and specific attributes of the response in implementation of 
the land reform program to the process and evolution of policy, legislation, and 
institutions; and 
(iv)  workshops at oblast and national levels, first, to understand key stakeholders' 
perceptions of the process and the impact; second, to obtain feedback on work in 
progress; and third, to obtain consensus on the findings and recommendations of 
the study. 
 
14.  The final step in the TA will be the publication of the study in the English and Russian 
languages,  with  a  summarized  version  in  Kyrgyz,  in  appropriate  forms  and  mediums  to 
maximize its distribution. An outline of the study report is in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent, comprising $257,400 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $242,600  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  finance  $400,000 
equivalent comprising the entire foreign exchange costs and $142,600 equivalent of the local 
currency costs. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation 
Fund and administered by ADB. The Government, through the provision of counterpart staff, 
office space and facilities, data and documents, and participation of the study working group, will 
finance in kind the remaining portion of the local currency costs equivalent to $100,000. In 
addition, MAWRPI will make available office equipment (computers, printers, photocopiers, and 
facsimile machine) provided under TA 3439: Capacity Building for the Ministry of Agriculture, 
Water Resources and Processing Industry.5 Appendix 3 gives the cost and financing schedule. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The Executing Agency will be MAWRPI. MAWRPI will form a study coordination group 
chaired by the first deputy minister with representatives from the Office of the Prime Minister, the

Republican  Center  for  Land  and  Agrarian  Reform,  Gosregister,  senior  staff  of  MAWRPI, 
representatives of World Bank- and USAID-funded projects, academia, NGOs, ADB, and the 
study team leader. Other study team members can observe the proceedings. Other relevant 
agencies can participate as required. The study coordination group will report to the minister of 
MAWRPI, and will meet regularly as required to provide feedback and guidance on the study 
process and working papers. The TA will be implemented over 18 months with an anticipated 
start in December 2004. 
 
17.  Up to 12 person-months of international consulting services will be required (person-
months are in parentheses), with expertise in land reform (team leader, 6), law (1.5), institutional 
development (1.5), agriculture and environment (1), social and gender development (1), and 
unallocated  (1).  Up  to  42  person-months  of  local  consulting  services,  as  required,  will  be 
recruited with expertise in land reform and study coordination (deputy team leader, 12), law (6), 
institutional development (6), agricultural economics (6), social and gender development (6), 
and unallocated (6). The unallocated person-months will accommodate extensions of the above 
expertise or recruitment of expertise identified in the course of the study. ADB will engage a 
research institute or firm in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. Resource persons for 
special  short-term  studies  can  be  subcontracted  by  the  team  leader  to  augment  various 
assessments, using up to 6 person-months of domestic resource persons or experts on specific 
topics identified to strengthen the study. A simplified technical proposal procedure using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method will be adopted for recruiting the research institute or 
firm. Equipment purchased under the TA will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on Procurement.  
 
18.  Workshops will be conducted at oblast and national levels to understand the perceptions 
of key stakeholders, obtain feedback on the study work in progress, and obtain consensus on 
the findings and recommendations of the study. Six workshops will be held in the three oblasts 
and two national workshops will be held: one on stakeholder perceptions at the beginning, and 
one on the findings and recommendations at the end of the study. 
 
19.  An inception report for the conduct of the study will be prepared at the end of the first 
month followed by a meeting of the study coordination group. Papers on work in progress will be 
prepared for the assessment of the process of land reform, the design and methodology of the 
quantitative and qualitative survey, the assessment of impact, the case studies, and the final 
report. The timing for these working papers and consideration by the study coordination group 
will be determined in consultation with the study team leader. Each quarter the team leader will 
submit to ADB and MAWRPI a progress report in English and Russian describing progress to 
date against an agreed-upon study timetable, problems encountered and action taken, and 
anticipated problems or delays in the conduct of the study. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to the Government 
of the Kyrgyz Republic to be financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation 
Fund  for  A  Study  of  the  Impact  of  Land  Reform  on  Agriculture,  Poverty  Reduction,  and 
Environment, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  These terms of reference should be read in conjunction with the technical assistance 
(TA) text, the TA framework (Appendix 1), and the outline of the final report (Appendix 2). 
 
2.  Up to 12 person-months (given in parentheses) of international consulting services will 
be required, with expertise in land reform (team leader, 6), law (1.5), institutional development 
(land management and administration, 1.5), agriculture and environment (1), social and gender 
development (1), and unallocated (1). Up to 42 person-months of domestic consulting services, 
as required, will be recruited with expertise in land reform and study coordination (deputy team 
leader, 12), law (6), institutional development (6), agricultural economics (6), social and gender 
development (6), and unallocated (6).   
 
3.  The unallocated person-months will accommodate extensions of the above expertise or 
recruitment of expertise identified in the course of the study. Using up to 6 person-months of 
domestic resource persons or experts on specific topics, the team leader can subcontract 
resource  persons  for  special  short-term  studies  to  augment  various  assessments  and 
strengthen the study. 
 
4.  A qualified and experienced research institution or firm that has a proven track record in 
working on land reform-related studies and has a sufficient pool of experts who have done 
conceptual, empirical, and policy research work on land reform issues in relation to agriculture 
or rural development, poverty reduction, sustainable environment, and institutional development 
will be engaged. The research institution or firm will undertake the study over 18 months and 
work closely with the study coordination group and Asian Development Bank (ADB). Particular 
attention will be given to the following aspects:  
 
(i)  Review  the  literature  on  the  experience  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  and  other 
countries  with  land  reform  measures__particularly  transition  economies__that 
examines  (a)  the  processes  of  land  reform  implementation  and  legislative 
measures (including laws pertaining to land use such as public and private, 
agriculture and nonagriculture); and (b) the impact of land reform on agricultural 
growth, poverty reduction, and the environment. 
 
(ii)  Prepare a comprehensive framework of analysis for the study that reflects the 
outline of the final report, the technical assistance framework, and the particular 
aspects  identified  below.  The  framework  should  identify  outcome  or  impact 
indicators, provide for the effects of parallel and enabling reforms that enhance 
the impact of land reform, and identify the critical issues that the study will 
address. 
 
(iii)  Identify  an  appropriate  methodology  for  the  conduct  of  the  quantitative  and 
qualitative assessments and clearly specify the links with the general analysis 
and the three case studies. Conduct the quantitative and qualitative analysis with 
appropriate statistical rigor. 
 
(iv)  Ensure that the comprehensive review of the involvement of funding partners is 
conducted in consultation with all funding agencies and projects. 
 
(v)  Conduct the three oblast case studies with particular attention to identifying both 
the common and unique aspects of the process and impact of land reform. The

case  studies  should  be  closely  linked  with  the  qualitative  and  quantitative 
analysis and the survey data disaggregated to capture the key features, including 
gender, indigenous groups, institutional aspects, and governance. 
 
(vi)  With respect to the institutional assessment, examine the capacity of the relevant 
institutions  to  implement  the  recommendations  of  the  study  and  identify  key 
constraints. 
 
(vii)  With  respect  to  social  and  gender  aspects,  pay  attention  to  (a)  how  these 
aspects  were  reflected  in  the  various  laws  and  regulations,  particularly  land 
redistribution and registration; (b) identification of policy, legal, administrative, or 
sociocultural barriers to full participation by the poor, the vulnerable, and women; 
(c) the role of customary law and its relation to the written law and the effects on 
access to full land rights; and (d) the gender effects of the dispute resolution 
procedures.  
 
(viii)  Conduct special studies identified in consultation with the study group and in the 
framework of the overall study. Such studies will be approved by ADB before the 
work starts. 
 
(ix)  Ensure comprehensive stakeholder participation in the oblast workshops and 
national  workshops.  The  final  national  workshop  should  have  international 
participation. 
   
5.  The  proposed  research  team  should  have  extensive  knowledge  on  the  conceptual, 
empirical, policy, and implementation issues related to land reform. Work experience on land 
reform-related  matters  in  transition  economies  (especially  in  Central  Asia  and  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic)  is  an  advantage.  The  team  should  demonstrate  how  the  study  will  use  a 
multidisciplinary approach in addressing the complex issues of land reform formulation and 
implementation, and the specific contributions of each expert on the team in the context of the 
outline of the study, and the conduct of the quantitative and qualitative assessments, the case 
studies and the short special studies, the workshops and consultations, and the coordination 
discussions with the study coordination group. The team should show how it will maximize the 
services of the international and domestic consultants and ensure effective coordination of 
activities of the team members in relation to the deliverables.    
 
6.  The team leader should have at least 10 years' work experience on land reform-related 
matters  especially  as  they  relate  to  sustainable  agriculture,  poverty  reduction,  and 
environmental protection. The team leader should have done quantitative research and survey 
work  on  land  reform  issues  and  should  have  (i)  knowledge  of  the  conduct  of  qualitative 
assessments and participatory approaches; (ii) work experience in project development and 
policy analysis that used a multidisciplinary approach in addressing development concerns; (iii) 
the capacity to carry out high-level discussions on land reform; and (iv) experience in producing 
large-scale research studies in publishable form and a strong record of publications. 
 
7.  The domestic study coordinator-deputy team leader should have (i) at least 5 years' 
work experience on land reform-related matters, (ii) strong knowledge of the major economic 
and social development issues in the Kyrgyz Republic, and (iii) experience in using participatory 
approaches in workshops and consultations with stakeholders. The person should have done 
study or project coordination work on international-financed projects. The person should be able 
to carry out high-level discussions with key government officials.
